Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2013 06:38AM Speedy4 wrote: Thank you for your positive words! I guess my thoughts are part of my process of trying to understand and come to terms with my dx. I will deal with it as I have done with everything else in my life...strong and head on. My BF always tells me I am the strongest person she knows. 2013 is going to be a tough year, but I will make sure I take the time to be grateful for what I have in my life....my children, my love, my family and friends! Happy New Year! Let's make it count!

Posts.Content: Speedy4 wrote: After being dx three weeks ago I've been questioning all aspects of my lifestyle. What caused me to get BC? I've maintained a pretty healthy lifestyle (or so I thought). I'm still waiting for the results of my genetic testing but I don't have a family history of BC. Did I have too much fat in my diet? Did I drink too much coffee? Too much bacon, sausage, meat over the years? Too much sugar? Too much alcohol? What changes should I make now? Cut out coffee? Should I not have a glass of wine with dinner? Has anyone else thought like this? I'm quietly beating myself up and driving myself a little nuts too... Dx 12/7/2012, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Surgery 2/6/2013 Lumpectomy: Right; Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel Surgery 2/17/2013 Mastectomy: Right; Reconstruction (right) Targeted Therapy 4/3/2013 Herceptin (trastuzumab) Hormonal Therapy Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2012 11:05PM Speedy4 wrote: Jojo, I too am new to all this. I just returned from meeting with a second surgeon and feel much more informed than a week ago. It may have been the initial shock or the the way the first surgeon delivered the information, but I now have a better idea of the path I will be on soon. I have to wait another two weeks to get an MRI and then will have surgery soon after that. It's my underdstanding that even if you decide to have a lumpectomy, depending on what they find, you may still have to have a mastectomy. Have you had an MRI yet? That should give your surgeon (and you) a better picture of what you're dealing with and what you have to do. I'm with you in wanting this out of me, YESTERDAY! Enjoy Hawaii!
Posts.Title: Now what?? jojo69 Linda-Ranching-in-the-mTns

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2013 06:07PM Speedy4 wrote: I bought two hats that have hair attached to them. The shade is a little darker than my real hair but it looks pretty darn good. The hats were totally plain so I brought them to an embroidery kiosk in the mall and had them embroidered. They look great! I've been wearing them to school all week and the kids don't know a thing. In fact I've had many compliments on how good my hair looks.
Posts.Title: April 2013 Chemo Group BeHereNow 6cats

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2013 02:40PM Speedy4 wrote: Had second treatment yesterday. Felt a little tightening in my chest during the latter part of the Taxotere infusion. Hadn't experienced that with the first one? The nurse kept a close eye on me and the MO on call listened to my lungs. All fine I guess so they continued. Drank lots of water and am forcing myself to do it again today and going forward. My liver enzymes were up according to my blood work from Tuesday this week so maybe I hadn't been drinking enough water before that? When I got home my BF shaved my head again. SE had buzzed it to a 3 last week but it was itchy and still coming out so I had her buzz it all the way down. I feel so much better! Weird what you can get used to really!? I even went without anything on my head the rest of the night (granted I didn't go out anywhere and it was just me and my fiancé home last night). My scalp is pretty dry so he rubbed CeraVe lotion over the dry spots. Virgin scalps is right! Gardengirl~you made me lol with your streaming thoughts of hair in between all the other every day thoughts. It is like that with all the anticipation of when the hair is going to start falling out!
Posts.Title: April 2013 Chemo Group BeHereNow 6cats

Posts.Content: May 14, 2013 04:06AM Speedy4 wrote: Half way done right Katie? Hope you're feeling ok. I go for my 3rd on Friday. Looking forward to being half way done as well! As for hair (or lack thereof) I've got the weird patchy thing going on too. The rest of my head is not totally bald/smooth. There are little hairs all around. Anyone else have this? Don't know if they are just hanging on or new growth?
Posts.Title: April 2013 Chemo Group BeHereNow 6cats

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2013 06:34PM Speedy4 wrote: Trying to catch up here as I've been out of commission for a few days. Sorta felt a fever coming on Friday and by Saturday I had chills and my temp was 102. Dr on call sent me to the ER. My WBC was very low and my body could not fight off whatever had gotten to me. They pumped me with antibiotics and finally I'm feeling better. Sending me home today! I will definitely be getting the Neulasta shot after my next treatment! I have the same feelings about losing my hair. I purchased a good wig and a hat that has hair attached to it so I guess I'm prepared but definitely not mentally prepared for it to happen. I can handle all the surgeries and chemo SEs but its the hair loss that's going to make me really fell like a cancer patient. Cancer SUCKS! We are all on the same journey and I am grateful for the thoughts, feelings, and experiences that are shared here.
Posts.Title: April 2013 Chemo Group BeHereNow 6cats

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2013 05:00AM Speedy4 wrote: Great news Tricia81! Sorry you had to deal with that on top of everything else. BeHereNow~ those hats are very cute. They almost look like Vera Bradley prints?! I'm a couple days behind you and have my hairdresser friend on standyby to make a house call when I need her. You are very brave! I finally told my 9 yo sons that I will be losing my hair soon. It went much better than I thought. One of my sons said he thinks I will look like a monk and we laughed and laughed. I showed them my wig and my hats with hair. It was very therapeutic for all of us! As for the UMX vs BMX decision. I had a lumpectomy and a R mastectomy. If any of the mammos, ultrasounds, or 3 MRIs had shown a speck in the L, I would have gone BMX without hesitation. Thinking about it now two months later, even with no family history of BC, I almost wish I had done the BMX from the beginning so I wouldn't have to worry so much about possibly having to go through this all again. Wishing everyone good sleep and easy days!

Posts.Content: Dec 25, 2012 04:28PM Speedy4 wrote: Similar dx and I feel the same as you do. I got my biopsy results just over two weeks ago, met with two different surgeons, and now waiting for results of HER2, BRCA, and to schedule MRI to decide exact surgery. I've only told three people and will not tell anyone else until my plan is in place. I don't want people to feel sorry for me or treat me differently. I just want to deal with this as soon as possible and keep moving forward. I'm an optimistic person too and won't let myself get beat. 2 years to get back to "normal"? I hope not! I'm only 42 and have two 8y/o boys. How do you know about node involvement already? Not the way I wanted to spend Christmas, but it certainly changes one's perspective these days :)
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed- MerryChristmas (sarcastic) smethot Kimberly1965

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2013 08:10AM Speedy4 wrote: andy6~it's my understanding (and I am by no means an expert) that removing or dissecting at least the sentinel node is the way to determine if the cancer has spread. I had 5 needles of nuclear medicine injected into my breast before my lumpectomy and my BS injected blue dye (to mix with the nuclear medicine) during surgery to be able to determine the path fluid drains from my breast. The BS follows that path to see which/how many nodes could be involved. Although the BS has a pretty good idea at the time of surgery, you won't know for sure until final pathology comes back. Hope this answer helped a little :)

Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed now MRI finds a 2nd Lump jfelice Camillia

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2013 11:11PM - edited Jan 4, 2013 11:11PM by Speedy4 After my dx on 12/7/12 my ob-gyn referred me to a BS. On the recommendation of a friend, I also went to a second BS (who I liked so much better than the first). I haven't had surgery yet because I want to have all the infomation possible to make the right decision for me. I had an MRI yesterday and have to return on Monday for an ultrasound for a "suspicious" spot in the same breast. If this spot is cancer, and they are too far apart from each other to have a lumpectomy, then I will have to have a MX. My BS also suggested I meet with a RO to discuss radiation options (possible intraoperative radiation). Hopefully surgery will happen within the next two weeks (@1 1/2 months after dx). After surgery I will meet with MO to discuss further treatment. I want the cancer out ASAP, and the waiting is really hard, but glad I didn't rush into any decisions regarding surgery! I was in the same boat as you...knowing very little about cancer. Since finding this site, I have become empowered and feel like I can ask my doctor important questions and be able to understand the answers too! :)
